II.

INTRODUCTION

Tajikistan  is  a  landlocked  country  bordering  the  Kyrgyz  Republic,  People’s  Republic  of
2.
China (PRC), Afghanistan, and Uzbekistan. Over 90 percent of the country is mountainous, and
most  of  its  6  million  people  live  in  the  western  part  of  the  country.  Tajikistan  was  one  of  the
poorest  republics  of  the  former  Soviet  Union  (FSU)  upon  gaining  its  independence  in  1991.
Along  with  the  breakup  of  the  trade  and  payments  system  of  the  FSU,  civil  conflict  and  major
natural  disasters  since  independence  have  contributed  to  a  dramatic  decline  in  economic
activity and consequent increase in poverty. The unemployment rate is estimated at 30 percent,
and  the  poverty  incidence  is  83  percent.1  The  Project  is  located  in  Khatlon  Region  in
southwestern  Tajikistan  and  covers  an  area  of  5,080  square  kilometers  (km)  south  of
Dushanbe,  the  capital  and  largest  city.  The  region  has  a  population  of  2.1  million,  comprising
one third of the country's population, with a poverty incidence of 91 percent. Economic activity in
Khatlon  Region  is  primarily  agricultural  and  includes  the  growing  of  cotton,  grains,  fruits,  and
vegetables,  as  well  as  raising  of  livestock.  The  region  accounts  for  over  40  percent  of  the
country's vegetable production, and many agricultural households cultivate fruits and vegetables
on small private plots for self-consumption and to sell in local markets.

3.

Tajikistan  reconfirmed  its  request  for  ADB  assistance  to  rehabilitate  the  country’s  priority

A. 

Sector Description

1. 

Transport

a.

Role of Transport

Transport  plays  a  vital  role  in  Tajikistan's  trade  flows  and  in  the  economy  in  general.
4.
Tajikistan's  two  most  important  products  are  aluminum  and  cotton,  which  account  for
approximately 60 percent of the total export value. Production of these goods is dependent on
transport for provision of inputs such as alumina and fertilizer, and for access to export markets.
The road, railway, and aviation subsectors carry out different transport functions. Roads are the
primary means of transport for domestic traffic. Railways are primarily used to ship transit traffic
between regions of Uzbekistan separated by Tajikistan's Leninabad Region and also serve as
the main mode for the export of aluminum and cotton fiber. Civil aviation provides an important
link for passenger transport over mountain ranges, which divide the country and are impassable
during winter.

severely disrupted economic activities and customary trade patterns, and resulted in a dramatic
decline in transport demand after Tajikistan gained its independence in 1991 (Appendix 2). Total
freight tonnage declined by 92 percent from almost 300 million tons in 1990 to about 23 million
tons in 1995. Similarly, total freight turnover in ton-km declined by 88 percent from 17.1 billion in
1990 to 2.1 billion in 1997. The number of passengers declined by 60 percent from 264 million
in  1992  to  105  million  in  1997;  passenger  turnover  declined  by  73  percent  from  4.5  billion
passenger-km  in  1992  to  1.2  billion  in  1996.  However,  the  formal  end  to  civil  conflict  in  1997
arrested  the  negative  trend,  and  Tajikistan  has  since  made  significant  progress.  The  positive
economic  growth  of  1.7  percent  in  1997,  5.3  percent  in  1998,  and  3.7  percent  in  1999  is
reflected in rising freight and passenger traffic, which still remains well below pre-independence
levels. By most measures, the size of the existing transport infrastructure is therefore adequate
to accommodate the current and projected levels of economic activity and traffic in the medium
term.  The  most  urgent  need  is  to  prioritize  and  carry  out  the  rehabilitation  of  the  most
deteriorated segments of the national trunk road network to support economic recovery.

6.
Road  transport  is  the  most  important  mode  of  domestic  transport  in  Tajikistan,
accounting for 67 percent of passenger turnover. Although road transport accounts only for 35
percent of freight turnover compared with 65 percent for railway transport, 80 to 90 percent of
railway  turnover  is  comprised  of  transit  traffic  crossing  northern  Tajikistan.  Since  the  transport
infrastructure inherited from the FSU was designed to integrate the republics of the FSU rather
than to support the economic development of independent countries, railway traffic between the
Fergana Valley and other regions of Uzbekistan must cross the Leninabad Region in northern
Tajikistan. If such traffic and import freight traffic are excluded, road transport accounts for about
98  percent  of  freight  volume.  The  railway  network  consists  of  three  unconnected  east-west
sections: (i) crossing the northern region of Leninabad, (ii) running westward from Dushanbe to
the  border  with  Uzbekistan,  and  (iii)  linking  Khulyab  and  other  major  cities  in  Khatlon  Region
with Ayvazh near the borders with Afghanistan and Uzbekistan in southwestern Tajikistan. Civil
aviation  accounts  for  less  than  1  percent  of  the  total  freight  turnover  and  25  percent  of  the

c. 

Transport Planning and Coordination

7.
Until recently, the Transport Department under the Office of the President acted as the
central  point  of  coordination  for  the  transport  sector.  Development  planning  for  the  different
subsectors  was  the  responsibility  of  separate  government  organizations.  The  Ministry  of
Transport  and  Roads  (MOTR)  served  as  the  national  agency  for  road  infrastructure
management, as well as management of road transport enterprises, including budget allocation,
work  assignment,  and  personnel  management.  Tajik  Railway  Company  served  as  the  agency
for  railways,  and  Tajikistan  State  Air  Company  for  civil  aviation  and  airports.  Each  of  these
organizations  was  responsible  for  preparation  of  development  plans  and  investment  programs
for  its  own  subsector.  During  implementation  of  the  development  plans,  the  Office  of  the
President  provided  coordination  for  review  and  revision  of  the  investment  programs  and  for
reallocation of investment funds among the subsectors.

8.
The Government’s Transport Sector Policy Statement (TSPS), issued in 1998, outlines
the  policy  directive  requiring  development  to  be  based  on  market-oriented  reforms  and
restructuring  to  improve  efficiency.  Since  transport  reforms  require  strong  coordination,  the
TSPS  calls  for  the  creation  of  a  unified  Ministry  of  Transport  (MOT)  overseeing  the  transport
sector,  with  primary  responsibility  for  formulating  policies  and  regulations  related  to  transport
services. The Transport Law, which was enacted by Parliament on 2 October 2000, provided for
the establishment of MOT. The Presidential Decrees formally establishing MOT and appointing
the Minister of Transport were issued on 25 October 2000.4

d.

Investments

9.
Public investment in transport dropped from about 5 percent of gross domestic product
(GDP)  in  1990  to  less  than  1  percent  in  1998.  Inadequate  financing  of  the  road  subsector  in
combination  with  damage  from  the  civil  conflict  and  major  natural  disasters  led  to  serious
deterioration  of  the  physical  condition  of  the  road  network  as  well  as  institutional  and
management  capacity  in  transport.  Major  reconstruction  will  soon  be  required  for  the  national
trunk road network unless adequate funds are secured for rehabilitation and maintenance.

10.
The Government is currently operating under a national public investment program (PIP)
for 2000-2002, prepared on the basis of the country’s fiscal capability and in consultation with
development agencies for possible external financing. The PIP includes 41 projects with a total
investment  of  $551  million  equivalent.  Seven  of  these  are  transport  projects,  including  the
proposed Project, accounting for about 21 percent of the total investment. The PIP, which was
approved  in  October  2000,  gives  high  priority  to  the  Project.  The  Government  confirms  that
adequate counterpart funds for the Project will be allocated in the state budget.

2. 

Roads

a. 

The Road Network

The combined length of Tajikistan’s road network is 26,000 km, consisting of 4,700 km
11.
of  national  roads  and  21,300  km  of  local  roads.  The  scope  of  the  network  is  considered
adequate  to  accommodate  existing  traffic  levels  and  support  economic  recovery  and
sustainable  development  in  the  medium  term.  Most  of  the  road  network  is  paved,  including
approximately 90 percent of the national roads and almost 60 percent of the local roads. Of the
paved roads, about 35 percent are asphalt concrete pavements with the remainder having only
a surface level of pavement. The major part of the network was constructed before 1970, and
inadequate maintenance and damage from civil conflict and recent natural disasters have left it
in a state of severe deterioration. MOT has classified 79 percent of the national roads as being
in  very  poor  condition,  20  percent  in  fair  condition,  and  only  1  percent  in  good  condition.  This
underlines the need to rehabilitate the national roads to extend their useful life.

MOT has jurisdiction over 13,600 km, including all of the national roads (4,700 km) and
12.
42 percent of the local roads (8,900 km). The remaining 12,400 km are mostly rural and farm
roads outside MOT’s responsibilities. Most of these were formerly under the jurisdiction of state
and collective farms, while a few were under the jurisdiction of local governments. Following the
breakup  of  the  state  and  collective  farms,  responsibility  for  maintenance  of  the  rural  and  farm
roads now rests with the local district administrations.

b. 

Road Standards and Safety

13.
Tajikistan’s  road  standards  and  specifications  are  based  on  those  of  the  FSU.  Several
studies  have  indicated  that  the  design  standards  of  FSU  state  roads  (national  roads  in
Tajikistan) are sometimes higher than those of the United States or European countries but do
not always result in optimum road design. For lower-standard roads, FSU standards for design
speed  and  cross  sections  are  similar  to  those  used  in  developing  countries,  but  for  higher-
category roads, they are excessive. The quality of construction of Tajikistan’s roads is generally
inadequate, mainly because of a lack of cost-effective construction techniques and independent
construction  supervision.  Based  on  a  review  of  road  design  and  construction  standards
undertaken  under  a  regional  TA5  for  the  three  Central  Asian  republics  (CARs)  of  Kazakhstan,
Kyrgyz  Republic,  and  Uzbekistan,  as  well  as  for  Mongolia,  standards  suitable  for  expected
traffic  trends  in  these  countries  were  prepared.  The  TA  findings  and  recommendations  were
discussed  with  the  Government,  which  has  agreed  to  adopt  the  recommended  standards  for
project design and construction.

The  Ministry  of  Internal  Affairs  maintains  road  traffic  accident  information  collected  by
14.

c. 

Vehicle Fleet and Traffic

15.
Recent  traffic  surveys  on  the  national  roads  indicate  average  annual  daily  traffic  on
nonurban roads of 500–3,000 vehicles per day, with levels lower than 500 vehicles per day on
some  sections.  The  civil  conflict  in  Tajikistan  and  some  neighboring  countries  has  resulted  in
frequent closures of Tajikistan's western, northern, and southern borders to most traffic, leaving
the  remote  eastern  border  with  the  PRC  as  the  only  fully  open  one.  Traffic  has  also  been
curtailed by the high cost and short supply of fuel, almost all of which is imported.

16.
In 1998, Tajikistan's vehicle fleet comprised 234,000 vehicles: cars 66 percent, trucks 27
percent,  buses  4  percent,  and  special  vehicles  3  percent.  Khatlon  Region  accounted  for  21
percent of Tajikistan’s vehicle fleet. The 37 percent share of trucks of the vehicle fleet registered
in  Khatlon  Region  is  substantially  higher  than  the  national  average.  Vehicles  in  Tajikistan  are
mostly old models manufactured in the FSU; many are not fully operational due to the lack of
spare parts. The maintenance of vehicles and operational transport services is highly dependent
on and limited by the supply of spare parts from other CARs and the Russian Federation.

d. 

Road Transport Industry

In  1998  the  Government  had  jurisdiction  over  81  road  transport  service  enterprises,
17.
mainly  regional  trucking  and  bus  companies,  and  owned  about  80  percent  of  the  trucks  and
buses in the country. In 1999, the Government launched a privatization program to separate the
provision of transport services. Most transport service enterprises have been corporatized, and
about 30 percent of the state-owned vehicle fleet’s trucks and buses have been sold. The bus
fleet  formerly  controlled  by  MOT,  with  the  exception  of  urban  buses,  is  almost  completely
privatized.  Less  progress  has  been  made  in  freight  transport.  MOT's  truck  fleet  is  in  a
dilapidated  condition,  and  approximately  80  percent  is  idle,  either  because  the  vehicles  are
inoperable or due to low demand.

18.
Tariffs for passenger and freight transport services are officially set by MOT. The tariffs
for urban, suburban, and intercity bus services were increased by 30 percent in 1999. However,
since the launching of the privatization program, most of the private road transport enterprises
are setting their own tariffs. Information obtained in the project area during field visits indicates
that tariff levels are indeed flexible and changes in transport costs are passed on to consumers.
For  example,  in  the  past  year,  tariffs  have  fluctuated  in  response  to  changes  in  fuel  prices.
Liberalization of tariff regulations for road transport services is expected with implementation of
the new Transport Law, which prescribes commercialization of transport services.

Construction and Maintenance

23.
Tajikistan  has  no  effective  maintenance  planning  and  management  system  to  prioritize
road  maintenance,  and  procedures  used  for  road  maintenance  are  outdated  and  need  to  be
upgraded to international standards. Road construction and maintenance activities on the roads
under  MOT's  jurisdiction  are  controlled  by  MOT,  based  on  the  road  subsector  management
system inherited from the FSU. Local construction and maintenance contractors are not allowed
to compete for work on the roads under MOT's jurisdiction. The maintenance of rural roads is
the  responsibility  of  local  governments,  which  may  hire  local  contractors  for  maintenance  and
rehabilitation work.

24.
Approximately 100 road construction and maintenance enterprises remain under MOT's
ownership,  while  9  construction  companies  (accounting  for  40  percent  of  the  scope  of
construction works undertaken) have been converted into joint stock companies. Most of MOT's
road  construction  and  maintenance  departments  are  organized  as  regional  conglomerates
consisting  of  specialized  technical  units,  except  for  those  in  one  region,  which  remain  as
individual  entities.  At  present,  MOT  has  limited  capacity  for  contract  administration  and
construction  supervision,  and  still  follows  the  inherited  practice  of  directly  assigning  road
construction and maintenance work to the regional conglomerates, which then assign the work
to  specific  construction  enterprises  or  maintenance  depots.  The  overall  capacity  of  the
conglomerates is limited because of inadequate expertise, obsolete equipment, and insufficient
financial resources to perform contractual obligations. The staffing pattern for road maintenance
is also inefficient with an excess of engineers at the supervisory level and too few maintenance
workers.

Government Policies and Plans

26.
The  Government's  policies  are  currently  in  transition.  Since  the  formal  end  to  the  civil
conflict in 1997, the Government has been trying to improve delivery of various social services
and  has  committed  to  maintaining  a  budget  allocation  of  37  percent  for  social  sector
expenditures.  In  March  2000,  the  Government  launched  the  drafting  of  a  poverty  reduction
strategy paper with the World Bank and IMF, and created a special working group to begin work
on  a  national  poverty  reduction  strategy.  This  working  group  includes  leading  academics  and
ministerial  representatives,  and  is  scheduled  to  complete  its  assignment  in  the  first  quarter  of
2001.  Based  on  the  Government’s  request  and  on  discussions  with  major  stakeholders,  ADB
will assist in drafting the national poverty reduction strategy and developing a poverty monitoring
mechanism.

27.
The  Government’s  transport  strategy  and  development  plans  are  reflected  in  the  PIP
and  TSPS.  The  strategic  objective  is  to  establish  an  efficient  transport  system  that  provides
affordable services to the nation, is responsive to the changes in the economy, and meets the
needs of the country through efficient allocation of scarce resources. The approach to achieve
the  objective  consists  of  (i)  establishing  a  policy  and  regulatory  environment  conducive  to  the
operation of a market-based transport system; (ii) improving sector management by limiting the
Government’s  role  to  policymaking  and  sector  regulation;  (iii)  improving  corporate  governance
and encouraging private sector participation; (iv) establishing appropriate funding mechanisms
and  adopting  market  pricing  and  user-pay  principles;  (v)  promoting  regional  intermodal
transport; (vi) improving safety and environmental standards; and (vii) recognizing the interests
of disadvantaged groups and providing targeted support to them.

Lessons Learned

ADB  has  no  previous  experience  with  large-scale  projects  in  the  transport  sector  in

Tajikistan. However, implementation of the PCIP, Emergency Flood Rehabilitation Project, and
several TAs indicates that (i) absorptive capacity is limited because of the tight fiscal situation;

implementing  programs  and  projects  in  Tajikistan.  Their  experience  indicates  that  effective
assistance requires project ownership and proactive involvement of senior Government officials

E.

ADB’s Sector Strategy

32.
The  objectives  of  ADB’s  interim  operational  strategy  for  Tajikistan  are  to  facilitate  the
country’s transition to a market economy, assist in postconflict rehabilitation and reconstruction,
and provide support for natural disaster rehabilitation and prevention. The strategy focuses on
three priority areas: (i) agriculture and agroprocessing; (ii) infrastructure rehabilitation, especially
for  roads  and  power;  and  (iii)  education,  health,  and  social  protection.  ADB’s  operations  will
promote  development  of  small  and  medium-size  enterprises  and  assist  in  reducing  poverty,
particularly for households headed by women and communities in remote mountainous areas.

33.
ADB’s  strategy  for  the  transport  sector  aims  to  promote  growth  by  removing  policy,
institutional,  financial,  and  physical  impediments  to  the  delivery  of  efficient  transport  services.
This  will  be  achieved  by  supporting  the  Government’s  transport  reform  agenda  and  providing
financial  resources  to  rehabilitate  the  rapidly  deteriorating  infrastructure.  ADB’s  transport
program for 2001–2003 will support the ongoing economic transition to a market economy by (i)
helping  the  Government  develop  an  enabling  policy  and  regulatory  framework  to  foster
economic  development,  (ii)  facilitating  privatization  of  state-owned  enterprises  to  improve
efficiency, (iii) promoting competition and private sector participation in the provision of transport
services,  (iv)  improving  cooperation  with  neighboring  countries,  (v)  improving  cost  recovery
mechanisms for road operation and maintenance, (vi) rehabilitating basic infrastructure, and (vii)
developing human resources.

39.

terminated in January 2000, and the budget allocation for road rehabilitation and maintenance
for  2000  is  well  below  the  1999  expenditure  (para.  20).  The  current  allocation  is  too  low  to

IV. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A. 

Rationale

43.
The  improvement  of  road  transport  services  is  vital  for  economic  development  and
poverty reduction in Tajikistan, which is the poorest country among the CARs. The breakup of
the  FSU,  civil  conflict,  and  major  natural  disasters  have  resulted  in  a  dramatic  decline  of
economic activity and increase in poverty. Poverty incidence is currently estimated at 91 percent
in  the  project  area  and  83  percent  in  Tajikistan  overall.  Rehabilitation  of  the  country’s  road
infrastructure  is  necessary  to  sustain  the  economic  recovery  now  under  way  and  to  reduce
poverty.  Roads  are  the  most  important  mode  of  domestic  freight  and  passenger  transport.
Maintenance  of  a  good  road  network  is  vital  for  the  agriculture  sector,  which  accounts  for  65
percent  of  total  employment  in  Tajikistan.  Roads  provide  the  agriculture  sector  with  crucial
access to markets for produce as well as sources of inputs, and the rural population with access
to economic opportunities and social services.

44.
The  project  road  links  Tajikistan’s  third  and  fourth  largest  cities  (Khulyab  and  Kurgan–
Tyube) with Dushanbe, the capital and largest city. The existing railway line in Khatlon Region
does  not  link  the  project  area  to  Dushanbe.  Since  large  sections  of  the  250  km  Dushanbe–
Khulyab  road  were  last  rehabilitated  in  the  early  1970s  and  are  in  a  deteriorated  state  due  to
inadequate maintenance, rehabilitation is necessary to extend the road's useful life.

Technical Justification

The Dushanbe–Khulyab road was constructed in the 1950s and was last rehabilitated in
48.

serious deterioration and damage. In winter, heavy snowfalls and avalanches block the road. In
spring  and  summer,  melting  snow  and  rainfall  cause  frequent  rockfalls  and  landslides,  which
often  make  the  road  impassable.  The  road  traverses  several  passes  at  elevations  exceeding
2,500 m and presents difficult driving conditions in its current deteriorated state. Rehabilitation
of  the  road  is  urgently  required  to  prevent  irreversible  degradation.  The  rehabilitation  will
address the defects of the road infrastructure by repairing and strengthening the embankment,
road  structures,  drainage  facilities,  and  pavement.  The  Project,  which  is  ADB’s  first  major
intervention for rehabilitation of priority roads in Tajikistan, will ensure all-weather road transport
services on the Dushanbe–Khulyab road.

49.

1,400 to 2,900 in 2001 and from 5,400 to 10,800 in 2024. The number of passenger vehicles is
expected to grow at a slightly higher rate than that of freight vehicles.

The  rural  road  improvement  component  linked  to  the  Dushanbe–Khulyab  road  will

V. 

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A. 

Economic Analysis

73.
The economic analysis of the Project is based on a comparison of the with- and without-
project  scenarios.  The  principal  sources  of  economic  benefits  for  the  Project  are  savings  in
vehicle  operating  costs,  passenger  time  savings,  and  benefits  arising  from  generated  traffic.
Vehicle operating costs are calculated separately for each vehicle type comprising traffic on the
road  sections;  savings,  which  are  attributable  to  the  improved  road  surface,  account  for  more

 21

than  85  percent  of  total  benefits.  The  Project  will  also  improve  the  access  of  the  rural  poor  to
markets and social services, and improve safety conditions on the road. However, as sufficient
data is not available to quantify these benefits, they have not been included in the analysis.

The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for the Project, excluding the improvement
74.
of  rural  roads,  is  15.9  percent  (Appendix  15).  The  EIRRs  for  the  various  sections  of  the
Dushanbe-Khulyab road to be rehabilitated range from 14.2 percent to 25.4 percent. Distribution
analysis  of  the  net  economic  benefits  of  the  Project  shows  that  vehicle  owners  and  users  of
passenger and freight transport will be the recipients of such benefits, while the Government will
have  a  net  economic  cost.  Sensitivity  analysis  was  carried  out  to  test  the  effects  of  negative
changes  in  the  key  parameters  that  determine  the  benefits  and  costs  of  the  Project.  The
analysis indicates that costs would have to increase by 35 percent and benefits decrease by 26
percent to bring the EIRR down to the cutoff level of 12 percent. Given the simple nature of the
rehabilitation  works  and  ADB's  experience  with  similar  projects  in  other  CARs,  such  changes
are unlikely to occur.

B.

Impact on Poverty

75.
A  poverty  impact  assessment  (PIA)  comprising  a  detailed  analysis  of  the  poverty
situation in the project area and the impact of the Project on poverty was prepared (Appendix
16).  During  project  processing,  poor  households,  farmers,  producers,  and  government
authorities  from  seven  districts15  were  visited  and  interviewed.  Khatlon  Region,  which  has  the
highest population density in Tajikistan, suffered heavily from the civil conflict and major natural
disasters during the 1990s. The civil conflict resulted in the loss of about 50,000 lives, creating
many households headed by women and a large refugee population. The abatement of the civil
strife in the region and the country in general has been accompanied by the return of refugees,
which  has  increased  the  incidence  of  poverty.  Khatlon  Region  is  the  second  poorest  of
Tajikistan's four regions in terms of individual per capita expenditures.16 At present, the average
monthly  income  per  person  for  a  typical  rural  household  ranges  from  $2.5  to  $4.5  equivalent,
substantially  lower  than  the  national  average  for  rural  households  of  $12  equivalent.
Approximately 91 percent of households in the region cannot afford the minimum consumption
basket and are living in poverty.17

76.
Agriculture and trade are the most important economic activities in the project area, with
manufacturing a distant third. Agriculture's importance in Khatlon Region has been increasing,
accounting for about 40 percent of GDP and about 65 percent of employment in 1999. Surveys
indicate  that  the  small  towns  in  the  region  rely  on  agriculture  to  a  greater  extent  than  small
towns  in  the  country  in  general.  Agriculture  and  trade  are  dependent  on  transport,  and  road
transport  is  by  far  the  most  important  means  of  transport  in  the  project  area.  Transport  costs
have a large impact on farmers’ incomes; surveys indicate that transport accounts for almost 20
percent of the final market prices for their agricultural produce.

77.
The Project will reduce poverty in its area of influence by rehabilitating the Dushanbe–
Khulyab road, which will result in lower transport costs for shipments of agricultural products as

78.
The Project will reduce poverty by improving rural roads. Surveys conducted for the PIA
indicate that poor farmers in the project area encounter three main transport-related problems
that reduce their incomes: (i) high cost of transport services, (ii) low availability of such services,
and  (iii)  damage  to  agricultural  produce  caused  by  bad  road  conditions.  Improved  road
conditions will allow a higher frequency of freight and passenger transport services along these
roads. The higher frequency of transport services will reduce waiting times and thus encourage
farmers  to  take  their  goods  to  markets  offering  higher  prices.  It  will  also  facilitate  access  of
wholesale  traders  to  rural  areas  to  purchase  produce;  greater  competition  among  traders  will
result  in  farmers  receiving  higher  prices  for  their  produce.  Improving  the  physical  condition  of
the  rural  roads  will  also  reduce  the  loss  of  agricultural  produce.  In  the  PIA  surveys,  farmers
stated that 15 percent of their profit on agricultural produce was lost due to damage caused by
bad road conditions, with poor farmers indicating a loss of 20 percent.

79.
The  policy  reforms  to  be  enacted  by  the  Government  as  part  of  the  Project  will  help
reduce  poverty  by  increasing  the  competitiveness  of  transport  in  the  project  area  and  the
country  as  a  whole.  The  Government  has  agreed  to  complete  the  commercialization  of  all
Government-owned  road  transport  operations,  excluding  large-scale  urban  operations,  and  to
privatize  at  least  25  percent  of  these  operations  by  project  completion.  Commercialization  will
include  the  ending  of  mandatory  tariffs  for  passenger  and  freight  operations.  These  steps  will
ensure  that  the  market  for  freight  and  passenger  transport  services  remains  competitive  and
that savings in transport costs are passed on to transport users.

The  Project  will  have  other  poverty  reduction  effects.  The  rehabilitation  works  will
80.
generate 450 person-years of employment during implementation. About 80 permanent jobs will
be created for routine maintenance after project completion. Also, the Project will stimulate the
local  construction  materials  industry  through  purchase  of  these  materials.  During  the
construction  period,  the  poor  located  in  the  project  area  will  benefit  from  the  demand  for
unskilled  labor  generated  by  the  Project.  Furthermore,  as  the  economic  recovery  in  Tajikistan
continues, the improved access to urban areas will make new employment opportunities more
readily accessible to the rural poor. Finally, while access to health and education facilities is not
one of the most important problems confronting the poor in the project area, the rural poor do
have  to  travel  to  urban  areas  for  advanced  health  and  education  facilities,  and  the  improved
roads will improve access to such facilities.

81.
A  poverty  impact  ratio  (PIR)  was  calculated  for  the  Project.  As  the  rural  roads  to  be
improved will be identified after project inception, the PIR was only calculated for the Dushanbe-
Khulyab road. The PIR, which indicates the proportion of benefits going directly to poor people,
is estimated to be 62 percent. The PIR will increase significantly when rural roads are included,
as the benefits from these roads accrue more directly to poor farmers. The PIR will increase as
the  level  of  competition  in  transport  increases.  This  illustrates  the  importance  of  enhancing

 23

competition  in  the  transport  market  not  only  to  fuel  economic  growth  but  also  to  help  reduce
poverty. With higher competition in the transport market, drivers and vehicle owners will pass on
most of the transport cost savings to transport users in the form of lower fares and freight rates,
thus lowering transport costs for the poor.

C.

Risks

82.
The Project is subject to the following risks: (i) delay in implementation, (ii) inadequate
capacity  for  implementation  such  as  weak  technical  and  managerial  expertise,  (iii)  inadequate
provision of counterpart funds, (iv) poor construction quality, (v) inadequate maintenance of the
rehabilitated  roads,  and  (vi)  unstable  security  situation.  The  Project  has  been  formulated  to
reduce  these  potential  risks.  To  minimize  the  risk  of  implementation  delays,  the  project
preparatory TA consultants prepared bidding documents to ensure timely commencement of the
rehabilitation works. Given the country’s limited absorptive capacity and resources, the Project
involves  the  use  of  relatively  simple  technology  to  avoid  major  technical  or  managerial  risks.
MOT’s capacity for project implementation will be strengthened though international consulting
services for construction supervision and the advisory TA. The use of international competitive
bidding  procedures  and  packaging  the  civil  works  for  the  Dushanbe–Khulyab  road  into  one
integrated contract will minimize logistical difficulties. To minimize the risk of poor quality control
during  construction,  the  construction  supervision  consultants  will  assume  overall  responsibility
for  material  testing,  monitoring,  and  other  quality  control  measures.  Regarding  the  risk  of
potential  delays  in  project  implementation  from  a  shortage  of  counterpart  funds,  the  country’s
absorptive  capacity  has  been  reflected  in  the  project  scope  and  the  proposed  financing
arrangements,  and  policy  dialogue  has  been  carried  out  with  the  Government  to  ensure
provision of adequate funding. The risk of inadequate maintenance of the rehabilitated roads will
be addressed by procuring road maintenance equipment under the Project, developing the road
maintenance  manual  initiated  under  the  project  preparatory  TA  (footnote  2),  including
maintenance in the capacity building and institutional strengthening components of the advisory
TA, and providing international training in maintenance planning. The continued improvement in
the security situation, including successful presidential and parliamentary elections in 1999 and
2000, will be a crucial factor for sustaining economic recovery. The project area was selected
considering UN security classifications to ensure safety and successful implementation.

2.
Located  in  the  heart  of  the  Pamir  Mountains,  Tajikistan  covers  a  territory  of  143,000

landscape qualities are significant within the road sections to be rehabilitated under the Project.
No known archaeological sites exist along the road corridor.

quality problems.

3.
The majority of Tajikistan’s population resides in the western part of the country. According

Badakhshan Autonomous Region, a territory that makes up almost half of the area of the country.
Approximately 1.5 million people live in Tajikistan’s urban centers. The majority of the population of

4.

Kurgan-Tyube  and  Dangara,  all  located  in  the  Khatlon  Region  in  southwestern  Tajikistan.  The
Project  will  focus  on  rehabilitation  of  about  80  km  of  the  most  seriously  damaged  road  sections,
rehabilitation of about 150 km of rural roads, and assisting the Government in developing a road
maintenance  system  in  the  project  area.  The  road  traverses  the  following  districts:  Bokhtar,
Dangara,  Kazamalik,  Kazimalik,  Khulyab,  Leninsky,  and  Vose  with  a  population  of  71,348  in

5.

percent.  2    Khatlon  Region  is  a  war-affected  area  and  a  destination  of  returnees.  The  area  was

17.
Access to safe drinking water has declined from 60 percent in 1997 to 48 percent in 1998.
In rural areas, only 15 percent of the population had access in 1997. Under these circumstances, a

Major Problems of Communities

18.
One  of  the  main  problems  for  the  communities  in  the  project  area  is  a  severe  lack  of
employment opportunities. In the project area, the unemployment rate was estimated at about 25
percent. The quality of health and education facilities in the project area is very poor, resulting in
severe health problems.

19.
Low agriculture production is another concern. One of the causes has been the lack of all–
weather  road  transport  facilities  and  good  road  transport  services  necessary  for  the  transport  of
agricultural  inputs  and  outputs.  The  majority  of  farmers  in  the  project  area  depend  on  transport

E.  

Expected Beneficiaries

20.
All  groups  of  affected  individuals  are  expected  to  benefit  from  the  Project.  The  Project  is
expected  to  have  a  positive  impact  on  socioeconomic  development  in  the  region,  to  provide
immediate  economic  benefits  for  farmers  through  better  access  to  markets  and  to  agricultural
inputs, and to generate employment in local economies. The improvement of 150 km of rural roads
in the project area will improve access to markets and social facilities for farmers living off the main
road.  The  Government  has  agreed  to  ensure  that  necessary  maintenance  of  the  rural  roads  is
carried out.  In addition, industries will benefit from an improved road network to city centers in the
project  area,  for  transportation  of  export  goods  and  improved  distribution  of  products  to  major
cities, including Dushanbe.

F.  

Vulnerable Groups

21.
No  major  adverse  impact  from  the  Project  is  expected.  All  road  sections  included  in  the
Project  involve  existing  roads,  and  their  rehabilitation  will  not  result  in  the  development  of  new
conduits  for  disease  transmission  or  increase  the  potential  for  disease  transmission.  The  Project
will not require any permanent acquisition of land.

22.
The  Project  will  have  a  positive  impact  on  social  groups  in  the  project  area.  Skilled  and
unskilled  labor  will  be  engaged  for  the  rehabilitation  works  and  for  routine  and  periodic
maintenance works after project completion. This will generate temporary and permanent income
sources  for  the  people  living  near  the  road,  and  help  lower  unemployment  in  the  local  economy.
There are no issues related to indigenous people.

G. 

Gender Issues

23.
No  gender  issues  are  expected  to  arise  during  project  implementation.  Given  the  difficult
physical conditions of rehabilitation works, women may not benefit from direct participation in the
works,  but  rather  through  indirect  participation.  One  opportunity  is  that  they  may  work  in  the
workers’  service  station  during  the  construction  period.  No  adverse  impacts  on  women  are
envisaged at this stage. The Project will build and use a gender disaggregated monitoring system,
to assess the impact of the Project on women in particular.

SUMMARY POVERTY IMPACT ASSESSMENT

The  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (TA)1  consultants  prepared  a  poverty
1.
impact analysis (PIA) of the proposed Tajikistan Road Rehabilitation Project. The analysis was
carried out in June and July 2000.

A. 

Introduction

2.

The PIA

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

(iv) 

assessed the extent to which transport cost reductions will be passed on to
passengers and owners of freight;

assessed the distribution of the net benefits between these and other groups;

identified the proportion of poor and very poor beneficiaries and the net benefits
they will receive;

clarified the assumptions and analysis behind the distribution analysis and
poverty impact assessment; and

(v)

3.
The main findings of the study are that the Project will bring direct benefits to the poor
and very poor people in the project area. This will be achieved by conveying a substantial share
of the net benefits from the main project road to the poor and very poor by decreasing vehicle
operating costs and creating employment opportunities. Maximum impact will be achieved if the
transport  sector  is  rendered  more  competitive  by  implementing  the  recommended  policy
measures.

B. 

Project Area

1.

Description of the Project Area and Project Impact Area

The  project  is  located  in  Khatlon  Region  in  southwestern  Tajikistan.  Since  the  main
4.
project  road  is  part  of  the  national  road  network,  which  provides  international  as  well  as
interregional communications, the Project’s impact area is considered to be the Khatlon Region.
The road serves the majority of the region’s population and economic activities, and most of the
impacts of the road rehabilitation project will occur in this region. However, the majority of the
impacts of the road rehabilitation project will occur in the project area geographically identified to
include a corridor of land on either side of the alignment. This road corridor falls almost entirely
within Khatlon Region, and covers an area of 5,080 square km south of Dushanbe, the capital
and largest city. The PIA has restricted its data collection and analysis to the project area itself,
while the whole region is considered when assessing broader impact issues.

5.
Khatlon is the most populous of Tajikistan’s four regions, with an estimated 35 percent of
the country’s total population of 6.1 million. Although Khatlon Region contains Tajikistan’s third
and  fourth  largest  cities  (Khulyab  and  Kurgan–Tyube),  the  economy  of  the  area  is  primarily
agricultural.  Cotton, grains (primarily wheat and barley), fruits, and vegetables are the primary
crops. Aside from cotton, much of the agricultural production is transported to markets where it

4. 

Access to Transport Services in the Project Area

10.
Based  on  the  PIA  survey,  outside  of  Dushanbe,  60  percent  of  drivers,  farmers,  and
passengers  using  the  transportation  markets  in  the  project  area  are  poor,  compared  with  91
percent of the people in the region. In general, the characteristics of the poor respondents did
not  differ  substantially  from  those  of  the  overall  group,  although  the  poor  owned  and  used
passenger  vehicles  much  less  than  the  nonpoor,  and  the  poor  used  buses  much  more
frequently. Farmers, traveling as passengers, most often brought their produce to market using
buses or minibuses.

C. 

Poverty Impact of the Project

11.
Infrastructure  projects  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  through  direct  and  indirect
benefits.  Direct  benefits  are  concerned  with  improving  access  to  economic  and  social
opportunities,  including  labor  and  product  markets,  and  enhancing  human  capital  formation,
especially  education  and  health.  Indirect  benefits  involve  increasing  efficiency  of  resource
allocation, especially the performance of markets, flexibility of adjustments, and the fostering of
economic growth.

12.
The  Project  comprises  three  components  that  impact  on  poverty  reduction:  (i)
rehabilitation  of  the  Dushanbe–Khulyab  road,  (ii)  improvement  of  rural  roads,  and  (iii)  policy
reform. Rehabilitation of the Dushanbe–Khulyab road is of strategic significance to the national
economy and is likely to stimulate regional and national income growth. The improvement of the
rural roads is likely to make only a modest contribution to national income growth, but is likely to
have a direct and significant impact on the daily life of the poor in the project area. Policy reform
will enhance the direct and indirect impact of the road rehabilitation and improvement.

1.

Poverty Impact of the Dushanbe–Khulyab Road Rehabilitation

13.
The PIA survey interviewed passengers, farmers, and drivers. The results suggest that
60  percent  of  the  users  and  drivers  of  the  Dushanbe–Khulyab  road  are  poor.  The  poor  use
buses more often than higher-income passengers. Their frequency of travel overall appears to
be about the same as the higher-income passengers. Over three quarters of passengers using
the  project  road  are  men.    The  occupational  profile  of  the  poor  passengers  did  not  differ  from
the  higher-income  passengers.    About  20  percent  of  the  poor  passengers  reported  working  in
the private sector, 20 percent for the government, 6 percent were housewives, 6 percent were

passengers  was  41,  about  the  same  as  for  all  passengers.  Poor  passengers  had  a  slightly
higher average household size (nine people) than passengers as a whole (eight people).

The results of the survey of farmers suggested that about 60 percent were poor.  About
14.
20  percent  said  they  sold  their  produce  locally  and  did  not  use  motorized  transport  to  reach
markets.    This  proportion  also  applies  to  poor  farmers.    About  70  percent  of  the  farmers  said
they sold their produce more than once a week, and about 70 percent said they did not use an
intermediate dealer because they were not satisfied with the prices these dealers offered.  All
users of motorized transport lease vehicles to bring their produce to market. The average age
for all farmers was 41, and 80 percent were male. This was about the same for poor farmers.

2. 

Poverty Impact of the Rural Road Improvement

15.
The Project will improve about 150 km of local, rural, and farm roads in Khatlon Region.
Local roads are secondary roads linking settlements to the national roads. Rural and farm roads
are small roads linking farms to each other and linking large farms to local roads. Usually, rural
and farm roads have a gravel or dirt surface and are quite rough. Local roads are larger than
rural  roads  and  often  have  asphalt,  concrete,  or  a  smooth  gravel  surface.  Usually  no  public
transport services exist on rural roads and traffic of motorized vehicles in general is low. Local
roads  usually  have  transport  services  (both  private  and  public),  but  their  frequency  and
availability vary greatly.

16.
The local, rural, and farm roads (henceforth referred to as rural roads) to be included in
the Project will be identified by the consultants and approved by the Government and the Asian
Development  Bank  in  accordance  with  selection  criteria  focusing  on  poverty  and  social
considerations,  traffic  levels,  costs  and  economic  returns,  sustainability  issues,  and  links  to
other relevant projects in the project area. The Government has agreed to selection criteria for
the  rural  roads  (Appendix  6).  Small  and  medium–size  holders  will  be  involved  in  the
identification of the rural roads to be rehabilitated in order to encourage active participation and
address  their  needs.  In  addition,  provincial  officials  responsible  for  the  education  and  health
departments will be consulted to address any issues concerning access to health centers and
education.

17.
The primary benefits that farmers in the project area will experience from improvement
of the rural roads will be (i) reduced loss of produce due to poor conditions of the roads, and (ii)
increased  income  due  to  increasing  competitiveness  among  traders  arising  from  improved
access  to  rural  areas.    Surveys  indicate  that  the  most  important  transport–related  problems
faced by poor farmers are the cost and availability of transport services, and lost income from
damage to agricultural produce caused by bad road conditions. All farmers interviewed by both
the  PIA  survey  and  the  appraisal  survey  stated  that  transport  services  account  for  almost  20
percent  of  the  final  price  they  receive  in  the  market.  In  addition,  transport  services  in  Khatlon
Region  are  of  low  quality  due  to  inadequate  maintenance  of  vehicles  and  lack  of  spare  parts.
The  resulting  infrequent  and  unreliable  transport  services  cause  farmers  to  spend  long  hours
waiting. On average, farmers indicate losing 15 percent of their agricultural profit due to damage
caused  by  bad  conditions  of  the  roads  leading  to  markets.    Poor  farmers  said  they  lost  20
percent of their agricultural profit due to bad conditions on these roads.

18.
Farmers interviewed for the PIA either sold their produce locally (without making use of
motorized  transport) or  they sold their produce to wholesale traders who, in turn, brought it to
the market.  About 70 percent of farmers said they did not use traders because they were not

 69

satisfied with the prices traders offered (on average, 50 percent less than prices in the markets).
In  general,  however,  farmers  prefer  using  traders  rather  than  make  the  long  and  expensive
journeys to the markets themselves.

3.

Poverty Impact of the Policy Component

19.
Since  independence,  Tajikistan  has  made  substantial  progress  in  increasing  the
competitiveness  of  transport  markets.  However,  the  Government  still  maintains  a  presence  in
providing transportation services. The drivers’ survey indicates that the Government’s role as a
direct provider of transport services does limit competition, and limited competition will result in
some share of the benefits of the Project not being passed on to consumers. If the current state
of competition prevails, a portion of the savings in vehicle operating costs will not be passed on
to  passengers  but  will  be  divided  between  the  Government  and  the  private-sector  vehicle
owners.  The  surveys  reveal  that  several  institutional  barriers  prevent  transport  markets  from
being  more  competitive.  Both  the  direct  and  indirect  impacts  of  the  road  rehabilitation  project
would be greatly enhanced if the transport market becomes more competitive, and drivers and
vehicle owners pass on most of their cost savings to transport users in the form of lower fares
and  freight  rates.  The  Government  has  agreed  to  commercialize  all  road  transport  service
operations,  excluding  large-scale  urban  ones,  and  privatize  25  percent  of  the  operations  by
project  completion.  This  process,  which  will  include  the  ending  of  mandatory  tariffs  for  freight
and  passenger  operations,  will  increase  the  competitiveness  of  transport  markets  and  help
ensure that project benefits are passed on to the poor.
